name: Cinema to superheroes
description: This Magnaphonic Projector and its double were originally used in the Tallangatta cinema in the 1930s.

key_work.title: Magnaphonic 35mm projector
key_work.brief_description:
Magnaphonic 35mm projectors like these were used as a pair. During a screening, the projectionist seamlessly changed film rolls between projectors, loading all ‘even’ reels on one projector and ‘odd’ reels on the other projector.

This one was used in the small town of Tumbarumba, nestled in the shadow of the Snowy Mountains. From around 1959 until 1965, it was operated by William James Burnell Newman, who ran Valley Theatres. It’s representative of early 20th-century Australian cinema equipment and would’ve been used before TV kickstarted the demise of country theatres in the mid-60s.

start.title: Magnaphonic 35mm projector
start.brief_description:
Magnaphonic 35mm projectors like these were used as a pair. During a screening, the projectionist seamlessly changed film rolls between projectors, loading all ‘even’ reels on one projector and ‘odd’ reels on the other projector.

This one was used in the small town of Tumbarumba, nestled in the shadow of the Snowy Mountains. From around 1959 until 1965, it was operated by William James Burnell Newman, who ran Valley Theatres. It’s representative of early 20th-century Australian cinema equipment and would’ve been used before TV kickstarted the demise of country theatres in the mid-60s.

end.title: The Kid
end.brief_description: A tramp cares for a boy after he’s abandoned as a newborn by his mother. Later the mother has a change of heart and aches to be reunited with her son.

constellations_other.name: Cinema to superheroes
constellations_other.description: This Magnaphonic Projector and its double were originally used in the Tallangatta cinema in the 1930s.

links.description: The Magnaphonic Projector helped usher in the era of “talkies”, with this one used at the rural Tallangatta cinema. Up until the 1930s the theatre had mainly played silent films like Charlie Chaplin’s The Kid.

start.title: The Kid

end.title: Modern Times
end.brief_description: The Tramp struggles to live in modern industrial society with the help of a young homeless woman.

constellations_other.name: Cinema to superheroes
constellations_other.description: This Magnaphonic Projector and its double were originally used in the Tallangatta cinema in the 1930s.

links.description: Written, directed, and produced by Chaplin, the multi-faceted performer also starred in The Kid as The Tramp. Arguably his most popular character, he also appeared in Modern Times.

start.title: Chaplin
start.headline_credit: France, Italy, Japan, United Kingdom and United States of America, 1992
start.brief_description: An elderly Charlie Chaplin discusses his autobiography with his editor, recounting his amazing journey from his poverty-stricken childhood to world-wide success after the ingenious invention of the Little Tramp.

constellations_other.name: Cinema to superheroes
constellations_other.description: This Magnaphonic Projector and its double were originally used in the Tallangatta cinema in the 1930s.

end.title: The Mark of Zorro
end.brief_description: Douglas Fairbanks impersonates a wealthy young Spanish noble who, in his proper person, is an indolent imbecile, the despair of his father and of his charming sweetheart. When he sallies forth a masked black figure on a black horse, the terrible Zorro, he rescues the oppressed and leaves “The Mark of Zorro,” a “Z” made with his rapier, on the oppressor of the weak.

constellations_other.name: Cinema to superheroes
constellations_other.description: This Magnaphonic Projector and its double were originally used in the Tallangatta cinema in the 1930s.

links.description: Based on Charlie Chaplin’s own autobiography, Chaplin starred Robert Downey Jr. as the title character in a biopic that charted his career and personal life. Kevin Kline played Douglas Fairbanks, who like Chaplin was one of the early movie stars and appeared in The Mark of Zorro.

start.title: The Mark of Zorro
start.brief_description: Douglas Fairbanks impersonates a wealthy young Spanish noble who, in his proper person, is an indolent imbecile, the despair of his father and of his charming sweetheart. When he sallies forth a masked black figure on a black horse, the terrible Zorro, he rescues the oppressed and leaves “The Mark of Zorro,” a “Z” made with his rapier, on the oppressor of the weak.

constellations_other.name: Cinema to superheroes
constellations_other.description: This Magnaphonic Projector and its double were originally used in the Tallangatta cinema in the 1930s.

end.title: The Mask of Zorro
end.brief_description: It has been twenty years since Don Diego de la Vega fought Spanish oppression in Alta California as the legendary romantic hero, Zorro. Having escaped from prison he transforms troubled bandit Alejandro into his successor, in order to foil the plans of the tyrannical Don Rafael Montero who robbed him of his freedom, his wife and his precious daughter.

constellations_other.name: Cinema to superheroes
constellations_other.description: This Magnaphonic Projector and its double were originally used in the Tallangatta cinema in the 1930s.

links.description: The Mark of Zorro was seminal to the genre of swashbuckling adventures and was the first time the vigilante Zorro – played by Fairbanks – was seen on screen. Almost 80 years later, Antonio Banderas had his Hollywood breakthrough with The Mask of Zorro.

start.title: The Mask of Zorro
start.brief_description: It has been twenty years since Don Diego de la Vega fought Spanish oppression in Alta California as the legendary romantic hero, Zorro. end.title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice

video_links.name: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice - Comic-Con Trailer [HD]
Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice - Official Trailer 2 [HD]
Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice - Official Final Trailer [HD]

end.brief_description: Fearing the actions of a god-like Super Hero left unchecked, Gotham City’s own formidable, forceful vigilante takes on Metropolis’s most revered, modern-day savior, while the world wrestles with what sort of hero it really needs. And with Batman and Superman at war with one another, a new threat quickly arises, putting mankind in greater danger than it’s ever known before.

constellations_other.name: Cinema to superheroes
constellations_other.description: This Magnaphonic Projector and its double were originally used in the Tallangatta cinema in the 1930s.

links.description: It wasn’t until the one-two punch of Desperado and The Mask of Zorro that Banderas cemented himself as a Hollywood star. The character of Zorro was a large inspiration for Batman co-creator Bill Finger, with a reference to this appearing in Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice.

end.title: The Mark of Zorro
end.brief_description: Around 1820 the son of a California nobleman comes home from Spain to find his native land under a villainous dictatorship. On the one hand he plays the useless fop, while on the other he is the masked avenger Zorro.

constellations_other.name: Cinema to superheroes
constellations_other.description: This Magnaphonic Projector and its double were originally used in the Tallangatta cinema in the 1930s.

links.description: Posters for The Mark of Zorro appear in the background of a Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice scene and refer to comic book lore that speaks to the character of Bruce Wayne being hugely influenced by the character when he was a child.

end.title: Chaplin
end.headline_credit: France, Italy, Japan, United Kingdom and United States of America, 1992
end.brief_description: An elderly Charlie Chaplin discusses his autobiography with his editor, recounting his amazing journey from his poverty-stricken childhood to world-wide success after the ingenious invention of the Little Tramp.

constellations_other.name: Cinema to superheroes
constellations_other.description: This Magnaphonic Projector and its double were originally used in the Tallangatta cinema in the 1930s.

links.description: Modern Times was supposed to be Chaplin’s first talkie, but he abandoned dialogue that he had prepared for the film as it went into production. It was also the last time he appeared as The Tramp. Richard Attenborough made a feature about his life, Chaplin.
